title: Elihu's Defense of God's Justice
shortSummary: In Job 34, Elihu responds to Job's complaints by defending God's righteousness and justice. He argues that God does not act wickedly or pervert judgment, and that human beings are accountable to God’s fair and sovereign rule. Elihu calls for wisdom and understanding, urging Job and others to recognize God's just governance over all creation.
timeline: c. 2000-1800 BC - Patriarchal Period, during the time of Job's trials

keyCharacters.name: Elihu
keyCharacters.description: A young speaker who addresses Job and his friends, defending God's justice and challenging Job's claims of innocence.

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The suffering patriarch whose statements about God's justice are being challenged by Elihu in this chapter.

definitions.definition: Moral wrongdoing or sin; a violation of God's law.
God’s righteous decision and administration of justice concerning human actions.
One who pretends to be righteous but is deceitful and ungodly in heart and actions.
Discipline or correction from God intended to bring repentance and spiritual growth.

outline.heading: Elihu Calls for Wisdom and Judgment
outline.description: Elihu begins by addressing the wise, urging them to listen carefully and consider what is right, while summarizing Job’s claim of righteousness and his sense of being wronged by God.

outline.heading: Elihu’s Critique of Job’s Attitude
outline.description: Elihu challenges Job’s words, accusing him of bitterness and associating with the wicked, and highlights Job’s claim that delighting in God is of no benefit.

outline.heading: God’s Justice and Sovereignty Affirmed
outline.description: Elihu emphatically declares that God is just and does not commit evil; He governs all creation impartially and holds all accountable according to their deeds.

outline.heading: God’s Omniscience and Judgment on the Wicked
outline.description: Elihu explains that God sees all human actions and will not tolerate wickedness; He hears the cries of the afflicted and disciplines the proud and rebellious.

outline.heading: Call for Repentance and Final Rebuke of Job
outline.description: Elihu encourages repentance and submission to God’s correction, while accusing Job of speaking without knowledge and adding rebellion to his sin.

application: Trust in God's perfect justice even when circumstances seem unfair, knowing He will judge rightly.
Respond to God's discipline with humility and repentance rather than rebellion or bitterness.
Seek wisdom and understanding by listening carefully to God’s word and the counsel of the wise.
Avoid aligning with ungodly attitudes that question God's goodness or justice.

keyVerses.text: Therefore hearken unto me, ye men of understanding: far be it from God, that he should do wickedness; and from the Almighty, that he should commit iniquity.
keyVerses.significance: This verse strongly affirms God's holiness and justice, denying any possibility of Him doing evil.

keyVerses.text: Yea, surely God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert judgment.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God's unwavering commitment to righteousness and fair judgment.

keyVerses.text: So that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto him, and he heareth the cry of the afflicted.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's attentiveness to the suffering and His role as defender of the oppressed.

keyVerses.text: Surely it is meet to be said unto God, I have borne chastisement, I will not offend any more:
keyVerses.significance: It teaches the proper response to God's discipline: repentance and a commitment to live righteously.
